Anticentromere antibody (choice A) is associated with approximately 90% of patients who have CREST syndrome (calcinosis, Raynaud phenomenon, esophageal motility syndrome, sclerodactyly, telangiectasia), which is also called limited systemic sclerosis. Anti-Ro (choice B) is also called anti-SS-A and is associated with Sjogren syndrome (70-95%). Anti-SS-B (choice C) is associated with Sjogren syndrome (60-90%). p-ANCA (choice E) refers to antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies that localize in a perinuclear fashion. These are usually directed against myeloperoxidase in the cell. p-ANCA antibodies can sometimes be seen in Wegener granulomatosis, but are more characteristic of Churg-Strauss syndrome, a medium to small vessel vasculitis associated with asthma and eosinophilia. It causes eosinophil-rich inflammation involving the respiratory tract and necrotizing vasculitis affecting medium to small sized vessels.

question: A 24-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-day history of fever and cough productive of reddish-brown sputum. She had a splenectomy 1 year ago. A chest x-ray shows consolidation of the right lower lobe. Blood cultures grow α-hemolytic. gram-positive diplococci. Immunity to the most likely causal organism is based on which of the following?
explanation: The correct answer is B. This patient has pneumococcal pneumonia, which must be considered in any patient with chills, fever, chest pain, and cough productive of purulent, rust-colored sputum. Streptococcus pneumoniae is an α-hemolytic, gram-positive coccus that grows in short chains. It can easily be distinguished from other α-hemolytic streptococci because it is exquisitely sensitive to bile and bile-like compounds, such as Optochin. It is the most common cause of community-acquired pneumonia and the most common cause of community-acquired meningitis in adults older than 30 years. The only recognized virulence factor of S. pneumoniae is its carbohydrate capsule (which contains acidic polysaccharides). Antibody to a specific capsule type is necessary to overcome infection. More than 80 capsule types have been recognized. The 23 types that most commonly cause disease are contained in a vaccine that is recommended for high-risk groups, including the elderly and those undergoing splenectomy. Increased susceptibility is also found in patients with Hodgkin disease, chronic lymphocytic leukemia, and myeloma. The vaccine should still be given to patients with these conditions, but it is less protective because of diminished patient ability to mount an antibody response. The alternative complement pathway (choice A) is important in clearing Neisseria infections. Individuals with deficiencies in C5 through C8 are at increased risk of disease from Neisseria. Neutrophils (choice C) will be found in the sputum of patients with pneumococcal pneumonia, but they do not provide immunity. They are attracted to the area by N-formyl methionine peptides found in the bacteria, but have difficulty engulfing the organism due to the antiphagocytic nature of the capsule. T cells and NK cells (choices D and E) are predominantly used for the clearance of intracellular pathogens, and pneumococcal pneumonia is an extracellular pathogen.

question: A 41-year-old woman comes to the physician for a pre-employment physical examination. She says that as a child she experienced two episodes of fever, headache, and sore joints following severe sore throats. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following sequelae of her childhood illness is most likely to develop in this patient as she grows older?
explanation: The correct answer is C. After an initial attack of rheumatic fever, an affected individual is at increased risk for developing recurrent rheumatic disease after each pharyngeal infection by beta-hemolytic streptococci. Any one of the manifestations of rheumatic disease can recur, but will usually resolve. The damage to the heart valves caused by rheumatic fever can lead to fibrous scarring and deformity, producing valvular dysfunction (particularly mitral stenosis) that may lead to heart failure in late adulthood. This is an example of a type II hypersensitivity reaction in which tissue-specific autoantibodies cause damage to host tissues. The inflammatory response associated with type II hypersensitivities is usually localized rather than systemic. The arthritis (choice A) produced by rheumatic fever is transitory and resolves after the attack has run its course. There are no long-term complications of the arthritis. Fibrinous pericarditis (choice B), like almost any fibrinous inflammatory response, is an acute process. Although the patient may develop some scarring of the pericardium, this is generally not sufficient to produce long-lasting consequences. Myocardial involvement (choice D) by rheumatic fever is typically seen as Aschoff bodies, collections of fibrinoid necrosis, lymphocytes, plasma cells, and histiocytes within the myocardium. When the event resolves, the Aschoff bodies will be replaced by discrete fibrous scars. No appreciable myocardial dysfunction ensues. Sydenham chorea, the neurologic manifestation of rheumatic fever, leaves no lasting neurologic effects (choice E).

question: A 33-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of a deep puncture wound in her right hand. A shard of glass is removed from the patient's hand, and the wound is appropriately cleaned and treated at the time of the accident. Twelve hours later, the wound becomes inflamed and swollen despite appropriate therapy. Which of the following molecules plays an important role in producing chemotaxis of white blood cells into this area?
explanation: The correct answer is B. In active inflammation, the complement system has been activated and C5a is being produced. C5a is a strong chemoattractant to neutrophils and other phagocytic cells. Other chemotactic factors for neutrophils include IL-8, fibrinopeptides, leukotriene B4, and formyl methionyl peptides from bacteria. C3b (choice A) acts as an opsonin for microorganisms. When the organism is coated with C3b, it is more easily phagocytized. C3b is formed via the classical and alternative complement pathways, but it is not chemotactic for neutrophils. IgM (choice C) is the large antibody produced in the primary immune response. It is not chemotactic for neutrophils. IL-2 (choice D) is a growth-promoting interleukin that stimulates the proliferation of natural killer cells, and T-cytotoxic cells, and T-helper lymphocytes, but it is not chemotactic for neutrophils. Lysozyme (choice E) is a natural antibacterial present in tears, mucus, vaginal secretions, and other body fluids. It is active against the peptidoglycan of bacterial cell walls, splitting the backbone structure of the peptidoglycan (N-acetylglucosamine and N-acetyl muramic acid polymers). It is not chemotactic for neutrophils.

question: A 15-month-old boy is brought to the emergency department because of sore throat, rhinorrhea. fever, and productive cough. A review of his records shows that this is the seventh time over the last 6 months that the child has been brought to the emergency department because of an illness. Prior visits have been because of infections involving the skin, ear, and respiratory tract. Laboratory studies show extremely low levels of serum IgG and an absence of CD19+ cells. Which of the following genes is likely mutated or deficient in this patient?
explanation: The correct answer is B. Bruton x-linked agammaglobulinemia is the only one of the humoral immune deficiencies in which there are no peripheral B cells (no CD19+ cells). The mutation is in the Bruton tyrosine kinase gene (Btk) that is required for pre-B cells to develop to immature B cells in the bone marrow. Adenosine deaminase deficiency (choice A) is the deficiency in one form of severe combined immunodeficiency disease. CD18 (choice C) is deficient in leukocyte adhesion deficiency, leading to failure of diapedesis, in which leukocytes are unable to extravasate to an area of inflammation due to lack of the common beta chain of integrin molecules. CD40L (choice D) is missing in hyper-IgM syndrome, in which IgM-producing B cells cannot receive the signal to isotype-switch to production of IgA, IgG, and IgE. The actual deficiency is in TH cells that are deficient in expression of CD40L. NADPH oxidase (choice E) is the enzyme that is deficient in chronic granulomatous disease, which will then result in an inability to generate toxic oxygen metabolites inside phagocytic cells. This would cause increased susceptibility to catalase-positive organisms, but would not result in diminished numbers of circulating B lymphocytes or reduced immunoglobulin levels.

question: A 2-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because of frequent upper respiratory tract infections. His mother says that he was delivered at 39 weeks' gestation and that the pregnancy was uneventful. A review of his records shows that he is up-to-date on all his immunizations. He has had three hospitalizations in the past year for pneumonia. Laboratory studies will most likely show a deficiency of which of the following immunoglobulins in this patient?
options: C. An immunoglobulin that binds to mast cells
D. An immunoglobulin that is an antigen receptor on mature naive B lymphocytes
E. An immunoglobulin that mediates antibody-dependent, cell-mediated cytotoxicity
explanation: The correct answer is A. Selective IgA deficiency (<5 mg/dL) is the most common of all the primary immunodeficiency diseases. The incidence reported in the United States has ranged from 1:250 to 1:1,000. Recurrent bacterial and viral infections of the respiratory tract can be attributed to a lack of secretory IgA (sIgA), the predominant immunoglobulin of the mucosal immune system. IgA is a dimer held together by a single J chain, and a secretory component is added by mucosal cells as it is transported into the lumen of the organ system. Children typically do not begin to develop severe signs of this deficiency until their second year of life because maternally acquired IgG (across the placenta) and IgA (in breast milk) protect the child for the first year of life. A pentameric immunoglobulin (choice B) describes serum IgM. This is the most important immunoglobulin of the primary immune response, but it is not important in protection against mucosal surface pathogens. An immunoglobulin that binds to mast cells (choice C) describes IgE. It is involved in the mediation of type | hypersensitivity responses and anti-parasite responses. An immunoglobulin that is an antigen receptor on mature naive B lymphocytes (choice D) describes IgD. Its only known function is as an antigen receptor on the surface of mature naive B lymphocytes. An immunoglobulin that mediates antibody-dependent, cell-mediated cytotoxicity (choice E) describes IgG. The binding of the Fc region of IgG molecules to natural killer cells, neutrophils, and macrophages can cause destruction of cells targeted by the antibody.

question: A 13-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of fever of recent onset and pain and swelling of his knees and ankles. He had an upper respiratory infection 2 weeks ago, for which he received acetaminophen. His temperature is 38°C (100.4°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 22/min. and blood pressure is 115/76 mm Hg. Physical examination shows erythematous skin macules with a clear center, arthritis, and small subcutaneous nodules on the dorsal aspect of the arms. A systolic murmur in the mid-precordial area is heard on auscultation of the chest. Which of the following is the most likely immunopathogenetic mechanism responsible for this condition?
explanation: The correct answer is B. The clinical manifestations fulfill the diagnostic criteria for rheumatic disease, a condition characterized by pancarditis (endocarditis, myocarditis, and pericarditis), arthritis, subcutaneous nodules, chorea, and erythema marginatum. A history of pharyngitis, otitis, or other streptococcal infections preceding the onset of the disease by 2-3 weeks is usually elicited. The triggering etiologic agent is group A Streptococcus, which incites production of antistreptococcal antibodies that cross-react with antigens of heart, skin, and nervous tissues. The antibodies bind fixed antigens and trigger an acute inflammatory response that eventually resolves with permanent scarring. This type of hypersensitivity response, in which autoantibodies bind antigens on cells or tissues, is classified as type II. Other examples of type II hypersensitivity-mediated diseases include Graves disease (the autoantibodies stimulate hormone production by binding thyroid-stimulating hormone [TSH] receptors) and myasthenia gravis (the autoantibodies interfere with cholinergic neuromuscular transmission by binding nicotinic receptors). Type | hypersensitivity (choice A) is mediated by IgE. Antigens bind IgE on the surface of mast cells and trigger the release of inflammatory mediators such as histamine and heparin, and then activation of the arachidonic acid cascade causes production of prostaglandins and leukotrienes. Asthma and urticaria are classic examples of this immune mechanism. Type III hypersensitivity (choice C) is mediated by soluble immune complexes, i.e., antigen-antibody complexes. Diseases such as systemic lupus erythematosus, rheumatoid arthritis, and various types of vasculitis are due to this mechanism. Type IV hypersensitivity (choice D) is mediated by T lymphocytes and often results in formation of granulomas. Granulomatous inflammation caused by Mycobacteria is an example of a type IV cell-mediated reaction.

question: A 47-year-old man with a history of polycystic kidney disease is awaiting a renal transplant. A living donor is found who matches the patient at A, B, and DR loci. Which of the following best describes this type of transplant?
explanation: The correct answer is A. A transplant between two members of the same species who are not genetically identical is an allogeneic graft. This is the most commonly performed graft in today's medicine. An autograft (choice B) is a graft from one location to another on the same individual. This is the only type of graft that will not experience rejection, even without immunosuppressive drugs. This type of transplantation is performed in coronary bypass surgery and in skin grafting following burns. Isografts and syngeneic grafts (choices C and D) are grafts between monozygotic twins. Typically, this procedure in the human is called an isograft; in other species it is called a syngeneic graft. Even monozygotic twins have genetic distinctions that arise during gestation and development, so some level of immunosuppression is still required following this form of engraftment. A xenograft (choice E) is a transplant between members of different species. Pig heart valves are often used in humans in this way.
